What I did- I reached out to a TEDxer when she posted about applications for her online event in November. I simply made an offer to help fact check for her if she gets a healthcare speaker. She happily accepted my offer as we will keep in touch about this development. 2/

@DerbyOTsociety I particularly like the AOTA/NBCOT student conclave. Being a conference exclusively for students nationally in the USA was a huge benefit... and of course, I still keep in touch with some of the attendees today. #otalk
Physical touch and quality time would be mine https://t.co/vL0tPWwkro

@Talking2MyElf @dyketape1 @AdhdAngsty @Finnattentive This stuff is fine. You just have to touch it up a little bit so that you still can authentically share, but in a more professional way. I actually will suggest one account in this case because I think your identities will mash together anyway in practice.
@hcldr A3. That will be rediscovering my touch in playing the piano. I thought I lost it after taking up golf 5 years ago! #hcldr

@irefusetosink04 It is possible because nobody knows when this is over. What I will suggest, if you have not already done it, ask how you will prefer to keep in touch with these people- social media or email.

One story when I accompanied my aunt in HK, her physio saw me sitting on a medicine ball. She was bewildered, "Why are you sitting on the medicine ball?" I shrugged and replied, "Don't worry! I had a lot of practice with this when I was in OT school!" #otalk
@dmay_ot @AndrewBatesOT I am not in for my 30 oz cold brew yet from Starbucks today. Will get that later. #otalk

One thing for sure- I am slowly pushing for change in OT culture. The change I want to push is- sometimes OT needs to jump on certain bandwagons sooner... or the profession will be left out in the cold by the general public... or the grounds OT has to make up will be immense!
I like this year's #worldotday theme of "Reimagine Doing". It's perfectly appropriate as societies are trying to rebuild and recover from the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.
@ShelbyC103 and when they get positive, they are taking their time to recover from this too so that they can be back to fight this battle again!
I like this year's #worldotday theme of "Reimagine Doing". It's perfectly appropriate as societies are trying to rebuild and recover from the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Now I really wished curating TEDx events could have been accepted as a conversations that matter topic at this year's AOTA conference! The new info during this COVID-19 would have been a perfectly timely topic to be showcased on CommunOT.

One difficulty as an #actuallyautistic healthcare worker during COVID-19 pandemic- it's not the easiest to cope with ever changing rules in infection controls in the working environment. Things can be one way today and different tomorrow.
@HeyItsSchmitty you should just move to where I live, once COVID-19 is under control.
My COVID-19 test on Friday came out negative. I am going to be extra sure here. So, I will plan to go back to work on Monday if yesterday's test results comes back by Friday.
Guess I will find out my results from Friday's test tomorrow. It must be stressful times for lab technicians right now in trying to analyze as many COVID-19 test kits as they can!

Post COVID-19 pandemic have made me give this advice to incoming OT and OTA students, "If you have huge aspirations for your career, please don't wait too long to try for opportunities you want. You don't want your career to be filled with regrets!"
Still waiting for my COVID-19 test results from Friday. I rather get cleared to work for both jobs I have than returning too soon to go back to one.
@GenesisBelieves and it is a time you got to be careful too! You should ask questions about what if you got positive for COVID-19 during this time.

I mentioned this before a few days ago. I will mention this again.

A false negative COVID-19 test can have serious repercussions for healthcare workers. If you doubt your test results, please get tested again!

Good news is- my COVID-19 case is relatively asymptomatic. 

Bad news- now I feel so mad and angry about my second TEDx now. At least I did the next best thing, I give the TEDx community a cautionary tale when curating future talks by healthcare professionals!
Today's #abcsofot = zzz's (aka sleep). Many COVID-19 patients could use that now. https://t.co/JjfhGXKVV0
@SamScott_OTA type 2 error is false negative. If you get a false negative with COVID-19 testing, you can possibly infect patients and you don't know it.
15% false negatives are way too high for quick COVID-19 tests.

@otnotes @SigningOTQueen @StacyTurkeOT @ktharris @OTMerrifield I think experiences now can be good teaching points to our FW students in the future, “Look at this COVID-19 pandemic. You need to keep an eye on what is going on day to day, but you also have to be aware of things happening around you that will affect your practice.” #otalk2us
Right now- I hope my COVID-19 test results come back. I have been waiting 10 days for mine already! #hcldr

@mrsmurphy_22 and also masks too! I bet if you are teaching the next big generation of OT's, you will be saying, "We are doing this because COVID-19 pandemic was a pretty significant event related to our profession."

I think 2021 will be an interesting year for many ambitious OT practitioners. 

COTEC-ENOTHE and APOTC are intriguing conferences to attend in 2021. Then there is WFOT in 2022. I know this will definitely give me a lot of headache in planning and budgeting this out.

@Laura_Does @Rachel_SOT @Cass_OT__ Actually, that's not the spotlight. 

When I told the TED community that I got positive for COVID-19, the support globally was amazing! I even got an email from TED/TEDx Community team saying that they are proud of me being a member of the TED community. #otalk
@ASVenturaCounty I have no choice since 2 weeks ago. I am an #actuallyautistic occupational therapist who got tested positive for COVID-19. I am waiting for clearance to get back to work.

@briellesymone and for my class, they want me to speak to them in person outside of their online pinning ceremony today. But with me being positive for COVID-19, they now have to accept me speaking to them this evening.
@GenesisBelieves and it is a time you got to be careful too! You should ask questions about what if you got positive for COVID-19 during this time.
Now I am another #actuallyautistic folk who got tested positive for COVID-19. It's almost like a matter of time because I work in nursing home settings nowadays.
@ASVenturaCounty I have no choice since 2 weeks ago. I am an #actuallyautistic occupational therapist who got tested positive for COVID-19. I am waiting for clearance to get back to work.

@CharJadee Stay safe out there, dear! I am actually still waiting to hear about unemployment insurance. I am on week 3 of not really working. If you suspect you might have it, please go get tested soon. I think I would have continued working had one of my rehab coworkers not tested positive

@catladyjustice @AskingAutistics Because I am tested positive, I have to wait a little longer to play golf... as golf courses reopened yesterday in LA. Golf is my stress/anxiety management strategy. I was not happy that got taken away.

@ChrisAlterio @_allisulli My SNF got pretty hard hit with COVID. I think now almost 30% of residents are tested positive. On top of that a few nurses AND a couple rehab staff (including me) are positive too.
@DinaBrownOT Well- hopefully no major decline. I heard someone got tested positive again after 2 week quarantine.

@SStendallOT @DerbyUni @DerbyOT 10+ residents got sent out overnight on Wednesday... and then a coworker found out he was positive from nasal test after negative from swab on Friday. The week before- some nurses got tested positive too.

@dawnjoyleong I know a colleague who got tested positive for a second time. Meanwhile, nursing homes and hospitals are easy places to catch this. Where I work is one of the hard hit cities in terms of nursing homes goes.

@lilririah and one thing- if someone around you tested positive, do the nasal test instead of the swab. Swabs have a relatively high false negative rate. Nasal is painful, but it is worth it because it is more accurate.
@OTunleashed So far so good. I think had a PTA in my work not tested positive on Friday, we wouldn't have been as vigilant to be extra sure!
@KrysBethhh I know a fellow OT friend who is dealing with worse- she got tested positive a second time.
@obrienrebecc 1.5 weeks minimum, but not be surprised if ended up with more than 2. Heard someone who got tested positive again after 2 week quarantine.
Now I am another #actuallyautistic folk who got tested positive for COVID-19. It's almost like a matter of time because I work in nursing home settings nowadays.

@RareCandace I agree it is not enough. But at the same time, I think we can’t rush reopenings or we will go back to square 1 all over again. We have some healthcare workers who are tested positive already. So healthcare workforce could use some reinforcements.
@QuartzDisc @SKP_SLP I find the opposite with dynamic teleconference calls. Almost no pauses! So, I literally take a deep breath and say to myself, "Hope I don't step on somebody's toes!" #autchat
My first taste of attending a virtual TEDx event. Getting to know some TEDxers from Asia Pacific Region. #stanbridgelife @ Monterey Park, California https://t.co/tSwkEvTwAn
@VicTORIously40 I make that recommendation because you said you don't taste bitter things. (I know my parents would occasionally make that pre-pandemic.)

@briellesymone I am on the other end as an adjunct. I have to make a painful decision to not be with my class if classes are not being online for the current term because I am COVID positive. But it's a sensible thing for me because last thing I want is to have my students get sick!
@LAlupusLady I know I will have painful nasal tests every week from now on. But it's for the best for everyone, including my family. #hcldr
@OTBrianNY if you say no fever and no cough, then you can't get tested, unfortunately!
@OTBrianNY if you say no fever and no cough, then you can't get tested, unfortunately!
@KrysBethhh I hope you get your results soon, too. Luckily I am asymptomatic so far. I have a PTA I work with who got negative for tongue swab, but positive for nasal.

@slooterman for me, I used to look forward to golfing every weekend. But even when golf courses would open eventually, it would be weird stuff I got to get used to (e.g. picking up ball from bunker, not shaking playing partners' hands, alternative ways to finish each hole) #autchat

@DisabledTimes @emkburke I don’t think there is a perfect solution here. There will be people who are hypersensitive to noise and/or level of noise. There will be people who are hypersensitive to light. So perfect solution doesn’t exist IMO.
